editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The gentleman of Venice a tragicomey
Presented at the private house in Salisbury court by her majesty's servants.
London, printed for Humphrey Moseley and are to be sold at his shop at the prince's arms in saist Paul's churchyard. 1655.

div.head: To the honourable sir tho. Nightingale baronet.
div.p: The poem that approacheth to kiss your hand, had once a singular grace and lustre from the scene, when it enjoyed the life of action; nor did it want the best hands to applaud it in the theater; but nothing of these is considerable, to the honour it may receive now from your confirmation and acceptance.

I must acknowledge many years have passed, since it did vagire in Cunis, and when it had gotten strength, and legs to walk, travelling without direction, it lost itself, till it was recovered after much inquisition, and now upon the first return home, hath made this fortunate address, and application to your patronage; in which my ambition is satisfied.

I know this nation hath been fruitful in
names of eminent honour. But in these times, there be more lords than noblemen, and while you are pleased to smile upon this piece, I most cheerfully throw myself, and it upon your protection, whose single worth to me, is beyond all the boasted greatness and voluminous titles of our age.
Be pleased to read, what is presented you, at an hour, you will dedicate to recreation, and preserve the author in your memory, whose highest desires are to make good the character of

closer.signed: The most humble among, those that honour you James Shirley

list.head: The names with some small characters of the persons.
list.item: Cornari a gentleman of Venice of a great fortune, but having no child, contrives to have an heir from his wife, and against the nature and custom of the Italian, endears an English gentleman to her affection and society.
Florelli the English gentleman of a noble extraction and person, much honoured for his parts, by which he gained much reputation in the academies.
Malipiero nephew to Cornari, a man of a violent spirit, and hated by his uncle, for his debaucheries.
Giovanni, (Supposed son of Roberto the Duke's gardener) whose noble mind could not be suppressed, in his low condition, and in love with Bellaura.
Thomazo, the supposed son of the Duke, whom no precepts, nor education at court, could form into honourable desires, or employments.
Roberto the Duke's gardener, an humorous jolly old man.
Bellaura the Duke's niece, whom Giovanni passionately affected.
Claudiana wife to Gornari, a lady of excellent beauty, ingratiated by her husband to Florelli the English gentleman.
Ursula wife to Roberto, a froward woman, and who much doted upon Thomazo her nurse-child.

div.head: Act. 1.
div.stage: Enter Malipiero, when knocks at a door, to him a servant.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: He has commanded your officious rogueship.
To deny him to me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To speak with my uncle sirrah, and these kicks
Shall fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Your howling will
be his cue to appear.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No insolence: I did but correct your knave,
Because I would not lose my labour sir,
I came to speak w'ee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Shall I not be safe
Within my house? hence.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You were best assault me too.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I must borrow money,
And that some call a striking; but you are
My very loving uncle, and do know
How necessary it is, your nephew should not
Want for your honour.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Hence; I disclaim,
And throw thee from my blood; thou art a bastard.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Indeed you do lie uncle, and 'tis love,
And reverence bids me say so, it would cost
Dear, should the proudest gentleman of Venice
Have called my mother whore, but you shall only
By the disburse of fifty ducats take
My anger off, and I'll be still your nephew,
And drink your health, and my good ants.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Drink thy
Confusion.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Heaven forbid your heir should so
Forget himself, and lose the benefit
Of such a fair estate as you have uncle;
Shall I have gold for present use?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Consider but what company I keep.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Things that lie like consumptions on their family,
And will in time eat up their very name;
A knot of fools and knaves.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Take heed, be temperate,
A hundred ducats else will hardly satisfy,
The Duke's own son signior Thomazo won't
Blush to be drunk sir in my company.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He is corrupted
Amongst diseases like thyself, become
His father's shame and sorrow, and hath no
Inheritance of his noble nature.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You
Were best call him bastard too, the money
I modestly demanded, and that quickly,
And quietly, before I talk aloud,
I may be heard to'th palace else.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou heard? I'll tell thee,
Were treason talked, I believe thy testimony
Would hold no credit against the hangman, but
I lose too precious time in dialogue with thee,
To be short therefore know. —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I will consume all my estate myself.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You do not know the ways without instruction.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do like that,
Let's join societies, and I'll be satisfied;
Let me have part in the consuming of
The money, that does mould for want of sunbeams
Within your musty coffers, I'll release you.
You have no swaggering face; but I can teach
Your very looks to make a noise, and if
You cannot drink or game, we'll ha' devices;
You may have whores, I that but live in hope
After your death, keep twelve in pension,
They wear my livery, I'll resign the leverets,
I can ha' more, I have a list of all
The courtesans in Venice, which shall tumble
And keep their bugle bows for thee dear uncle,
we'll teach thee a thousand ways.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It sha'not need,
I shall take other courses with my wealth,
And none of you shall share in't. I have a humour
To turn my money into hospitals;
Your riots come not thither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But we may,
Drink, and diseases are the ways to that too,
But will you turn a master of this college
You talk of uncle? this same hospital?
And lay out money to buy wooden legs
For crippled men of war, invite to your cost
Men that have lost their noses in hot service?
Live and converse with rotten bawds and bone-setters,
Provide pensions for surgery, and hard words
That eat like corrosives, and more afflict
The patient? but you'll save charges, I consider
My aunt, your wife —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: How dar'st thou mention her
With thy foul breath.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: May be excellent at composing
Of medicines for corrupted lungs, impostumes
At making plasters, diet drinks, and in charity
Will be a great friend to the pox.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And you'll be famous by't, I may in time
As I said before, if lust, and wine assist me,
Grow unsound too, and be one of her patients;
And have an office after in her household
To prepare lint, and cerecloths, empty veins,
And be controller of the crutches, o
The world would praise the new foundation
Of such a pest house, and the poor souls drink
Your health at every festival in hot porridge.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Art thou of kin to me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I think I am,
as near as your brother's eldest son, who had
No competent estate from his own parents.
And for that reason by wise nature was
Ordained to be your heir that have enough uncle.
The fates must be obeyed, and while your land
Is fastened to my name for want of males,
Which I do hope, if my aunt hold her barrenness
You will never bang out of her sheaf, I may
Be confident to write myself your nephew.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou hast no seeds of goodness in thee, but
I may find ways to cross your hopeful interest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You'll find no seeds in my aunt's parsley-bed
I hope, and then I'm safe, but take your course,
Supply me for the present, for your honour —
The ducats come.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: As you would not
Have me pull down this house, when you are dead
And build a stews, the ducats come.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Because I do not cut your throat, that were
The way to disinherit myself quaintly.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Canst thou not steal? And so deserve a hanging?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes I can, and am often tempted, but I won't
Do you that mighty wrong, to let what you have
So long, and with so little conscience gathered,
Be lost in confiscation by my felony.
I know a way worth ten on't; yet thus much
I'll bind it with an oath, when I turn thief,
Your gold shall be the first I will make bold with,
In the mean time lend me the trifling ducats,
And do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Not a muccinigo
To save thee from the galleys.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No? the galleys!
Must I shift still? remember, and die shortly
I'll live, I will, and rather than not be
Revenged on thy estate, I will eat roots
Course ones I mean, love, and undo an herbwife
With eating up her salads, live and lap
Only in barley water, think on't yet,
I am now for wine, you know not what that heat
May do, the injury being so fresh, I may
Return, and you'll repent.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis more than I
Can hope of thee, go to your rabble sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You a gentleman of Venice? but remember,
A pox 'a your wealth, I will do something
To deserve the halter, that I may disgrace
The house I came on, and at my execution
Make such a speech, as at the report, thou shalt
Turn desperate, and with the remnant of
My cord go hang thyself, and that way forfeit
All thy estate when I am dead, I'll do
Or this, or something worse to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He's lost, this doth new fire my resolution;
See if your mistress be yet ready sirrah,
Say I expect her. Exit servant.
My blood is almost in a fever with
My passion, but Claudiana may cure all,
Whom I have wrought with importunity
To be spectator at the exercise
This day ith' academy, here she comes,

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Ever to obey you sir,
But if you would consider yet, you may
Be kind, and let me stay, I dare not think
You are less careful of my honour, but
you gave once command with my consent too,
Not to be seen too much abroad.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I did.
I must confess Claudiana, I had thoughts
And scruples which thy innocence hath cleared,
And though our nice Italian everywhere
Impose severely on their wives; I should
Be unjust to make thee still a prisoner to
Thy melancholy chamber, take the air,
'Tis for thy health, and while I wait upon thee,
Thou art above the tongue, and wound of scandal.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: I know your presence takes off all dishonour,
But —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No more, I charge thee by thy love,
And to convince all arguments against it;
I have provided so, thou shalt observe
Unseen the bold contentions of art,
And action.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I shall be angry
If my desires be played withal, pretend not
With purpose to delude me, I have blessings
Stored in thy health, but if you practise any
Infirmity to cross my will, that aims
At the security of thy health and honour —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This becomes Claudiana,
I will think thee in a kiss, prepare
The gondola.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And I on thee,
The treasure of my eyes, and heart.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Where is my son Giovanni sirrah?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: He went two hours ago to the academy ,
To see the exercise today.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: How's that?
What business has he there, pray amongst gentlemen?
He does presume too much.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: You give him to much rein; 'twould become him
To follow his profession, and not look after
Those gentlemanly sports.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No tempest wife,
No thundering Ursula, am not I the Duke's
Chief gardener, ha? and shall I make my son
A drudge; confine him here to be an earthworm,
Live like a mole, or make it his last blessing
To plant, and order quickset; let him walk,
And see the fashions.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: He has cost you sweetly
To bring him up, what use had he of learning?
What benefit, but to endanger us,
And with his 'Poring upon books at midnight,
To set the house on fire, let him know how
To rule a spade, as you ha' done.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: He does so,
And knows how to inoculate my Ursula,
My nimble tongue, no more: because he read
The story of Xanthippe tother night
That could out-talk a drum, and sound a point
Of war to her husband honest Socrates,
You took a pet; he shall abroad sometimes
And read and write till his head ache. Go to

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: So, so, the Duke's garden shall be then
Well looked to, he deserves a pension,
For reading Amadis de Gaul, and Guzman,
And don Quixot, but I'll read him a lecture.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You will? offer but to bark at him,
And I will send him to the university
To anger thee, nay he shall learn to fence too,
And fight with thee, at twenty several weapons
except thy two edged tongue, a little thing
Would make me entertain a dancing master,
Peace, or I will destroy thy kitchen Ursula,
Disorder all thy trinkets, and in stead
Of brass and pewter, hang up viol de gamba,
I'll set an organ up at thy bed's head,
And he shall play upon't: what tyrannical
To thy own flesh and blood, to Giovanni?
My heir, my only boy? fetch me a tailor,
He shall have new clothes, and no more be warm
With the reversion of your petticoats,
Do not provoke me, what imperious?
Get you in, or I will swinge you, go, and weed.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Now for vexation could I cry my heart out.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sirrah stay you, and is Giovanni gone
To'th' academy saist?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes sir, they say,
There is an English gentleman, that wins
The garland from 'em all at every exercise,
One of the court told my young master on't,
(As he inquired of every gentleman
Comes in to'th' garden, what's the news abroad)

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And does he not tell thee tales and dainty storeys
Sometimes?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: O, of Tamburlaine, and the great Turk, and all
His concubines, he knows 'em to a hair,
He is more perfect in the chronicles
Then I am in my prayers.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: And talks a battle, as he were among 'em,
He tickles all your turbans, and in a rage,
Wishes he had the cutting of their cabbages
To show what house he came on.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: O sir he has a pestilent memory,
he told me tother day there was another
World in the moon, and that the world we live in
Shines like to that, to people that live there,
How many miles it is about the earth,
How many to the stars, I fear he will
Be mad, if he read much, 'tis just like ravening,
And such hard words would choke me to repeat 'em.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: We are familiar.
You are his father, and he dares not lie
To you, to me he may talk any thing,
He knows my understanding to an inch.
Would you would speak to him though, to take a little
More pains, 'tis I do all the droil, the dirtwork:
When I am digging; he is cutting unicorns,
And lions in some hedge, or else devising
New knots upon the ground, drawing out crowns
And the Dukes arms, castles and cannons in 'em,
Here galleys, there a ship giving a broad side,
Here out of turf he carves a senator
With all his robes, making a speech to time
That grows hard by, and twenty curiosities,
I think he means to embroider all the garden
Shortly, but I do all the course-work; here's
My mistress again.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: I must be patient: your son's not come yet

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Why now thou art ursa maior, love thy whelp,
And we are friends.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Was not the Duke's son here?
I fear he is sick, that I have not seen him
These two days in the garden.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Ay, there's a gentleman indeed.
I dreamt on him last night, pray heaven he be
In health, I prithee make enquiry,
There's a gentleman, and you talk of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I know not, but my mistress would send me
To know the state of his body.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Why, how now Ursula? sirrah about you business,
And spare that inquisition, what hath
Your impudence to do with the Duke's son?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Have not I to do that gave him suck?
I hope I was his nurse, and it becomes me
To inquire of his health, he is the very pearl
Of courtesy, not proud nor coy I warrant you,
But gentle as my Sunday muff.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: I am the better when I look upon him,
There 'A gentleman, and you talk of a gentleman,
So complete, so affable, a scholar too,
If I could understand him, prithee sweet heart,
Get me with child that I may long a little.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: For a piece of the Duke's son?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: I shall ne'er forget how prettily
He took the nipple, and would play, and prattle himself
Asleep I warrant you, but he's now a man,
A great man, and he remembers me still:
There's a gentleman, and you talk of a gentleman.

div.stage: Enter Marino meeting Candiano a senator.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Spare
your haste, all's done.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The English gentleman is still victorious ▪
All praises flow upon him, he has deposed
Our city, which hath now resigned her laurel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The same, in's face the promise
Of a most noble nature.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Pray give me leave, to understand your language,
For this, so much above me, scarce will be,
(When I'm less ignorant), worth my thanks,

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: This is
We know pretence of modesty, we must
Congratulate your triumph.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For this time
I'll be content your praises shall abuse me.
Who are these?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Friends and honourers of your worth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I see that courtesy is native here,
All the reward I can return, must be
To speak abroad the nobleness of Venice
For so much grace to an unworthy stranger.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We must resolve to send new forces
And speedily, the flame will else endanger
Venice itself.

sp.speaker: Senator
sp.l: This town lost will encourage
The insulting genoese.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I look when you will ask me leave to trail
A pike, and purchase honour in these wars.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I have not been well since I was last
let blood, and therefore if you please, I would
Be excused till the next wars, and then have at 'em ▪
By that time I shall be a better rapier man.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This fool is the dishonour of my blood,
He declines all that's noble, and obeys
A base and vulgar appetite, he dwells
Like a disease within my name, but 'tis
Heaven's punishment, what are they?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: All strangers, but among them one
In whom you may read something worth your grace,
An English gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He, to whom fame
Gives the honour of our exercises, nature
With such an active heat might have built up
My son, but he's cursed to live a shadow,Marino fetches Florelli to kiss the Duke's hand.
Welcome sir to Venice.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He shall kiss my hand too, I am the Duke's son.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thomazo give that gentleman
A box oth' ear.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: He won't take it kindly,
He is one —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Will strike again, is not that it?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I would not use a stranger so discourteously, or else —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Embrace him then, and make yourself worthy of
His friendship and converse, you'll gain more honour
Than the empty title of your birth can bring ye:
But to the great affair; the war, your counsels.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: My father bids me embrace you sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I shall
Be proud when I can do you any service.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Gentlemen, pray know me every one ▪
I am the Duke's son, my name's signior Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You do us too great honour.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We had no object worth our envy sir
Till you arrived, you have at once dishonoured,
And made our Venice fortunate.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Malipiero, let's bid 'em welcome in rich wine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I attend you sir.
This fellow must not live to boast his trophies,
He may supplant me too, if he converse
Too freely with Thomazo, whose course wit
Is all the stock I live by, please you gentlemen
To walk.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I would not have the way
But that you are a stranger.

div.head: Act. 2.
div.stage: Enter Cornari and Claudiana, as in the Duke garden.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou hast done well
My Claudiana, very well, who dare
Traduce thee for't? am I not careful of thee?
I prithee give me thy opinion
Who deserved best of all the gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I have not art enough to judge.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But thou
Hast fancy, and a liberal thought, that may
Bestow thy praise on some or other, tell me
If thou hadst been to give the garland, prithee
whose head should wear it? though we ha' not judgement
To examine, and prepare our justice; yet
Where men contend for any victory,
Affection may dispose us, and by some
Secret in nature we do still incline
To one, and guard him with our wishes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I hope
This is but mirth.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: By my regard to thy
Fair honour, nothing else, it sha'not rise
To a dispute, who has the vote today
Of all the gentlemen? I must know.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: They are
To me indifferent.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: So is my question, but I must have more,
It cannot be but some man must deserve
More print and poise in thy opinion,
Speak as thou lovest me Claudiana.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir,
Your inquisition is not without change
Of looks upon me, and those smiles you ask with,
Are not your own I fear.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay, than you dally,
And undo that obedience, I so much
Commended.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yet again?
The man, tell me the man?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The gentleman
That best deserves in thy opinion.
I shall be angry: what deny to give me
This trivial satisfaction? the expense
Of a little breath? why do you tremble so?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Alas, I know not what to answer, this
must needs engender fears in my cold bosom,
That my poor honour is betrayed, and I
Stand in your thoughts suspected of some guilt
I never understood, if the report
Of malice have abused me to your ear,
(For by yourself I am all innocent)

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, your question
Hath frighted me, 'tis strange, and killing to
My tender apprehension.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You're a fool
To be thus troubled, and but that I know
The purity of thy faith to me, this language
Would make me jealous, 'tis an ill dress't passion,
And paleness, that becomes not Claudiana
To wear upon her modest cheek, I see
Thy heart sick in thy eyes, be wise, and cure it,
My question was but mirth, without the sense
Of the least scruple in myself, or meaning
To discompose one cheerful look.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And you as safely might have answered me.
As I had casually asked the time o'th day;
What dressing you delight in, or what gown
You most affect to wear.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Once more I ask you pardon, you restore me,
And I am now secured by your clear goodness,
To give my weak opinion —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Of the man
That did appear in thy thoughts to deserve
Most honour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You'll excuse a woman's verdict,
My voice is for the stranger sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why so!
You like him best; what horror was in this
Poor question now? you mean the English man?

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.p: The same, most graceful in his parts and person.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I'm satisfied, and we both meet
In one opinion too, he is indeed
The bravest cavalier, what hurt's in all
This now? I see you can distinguish, wert thou
A virgin Claudiana, thou wouldst find
Gentle and easy thoughts to entertain
So promising a servant; I should be
Taken with him myself, were I a lady,
And loved a man.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam Bellaura the Duke's charge is entered
The garden, let's choose another walk.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why you are conceited sirrah, does wit
Grow in this garden?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yea, madam while I am in't, I am a slip
Myself.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis pity, but thou shouldst be kept with watering,

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: There's wit in every flower, if you can gather it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am of thy mind.
But what's the wit prithee of yonder tulip?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: You may read there the wit of a young courtier.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Pride, and show of colours, a fair promising,
Dear when 'tis bought, and quickly comes to nothing.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: If you attempt
Madam to pluck a rose, I shall find a moral in't.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: That grows with potherbs, and poor roots, which here
Would be accounted weeds, course things of profit,
whose end is kitchen physic, and sound health;
Two things not now in fashion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your wit dances.
Where learned you all these morals?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I but glean
From my young master Giovanni madam,
He'll run division upon every flower,
He has a wit able to kill the weeds,
And ripen all the fruit in the Duke's orchard.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: He went betimes to'th academy,
He is at all the exercises, we
Shall ha' such news when he comes home.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why does
Your master (Being rich) suffer his son
To work i'th garden?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: My master? he's an honest mortal man madam,
It is my mistress, that commands him to't,
A shrew, and loves him not, but 'tis no matter;
I ha' the better company, he's here.
I'll leave him to you madam, I must now
Water my plants.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why? how now Giovanni, you frequent I hear
The academies.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: When I can dispense
Madam, with time, and these employments, I
Intrude a glad spectator at those schools
Of wit and action, which although I cannot
Reach, I am willing to admire, and look at
With pity of myself lost here in darkness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: By this expression I may conceive
How much you have improved, and gained a language
Courtly, and modest.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Madam, you are pleased
To make my uneven frame of words your mirth.
I profess nothing but an humble ignorance,
And I repent not, if by any way
(My duty and manners safe) it may delight you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Indeed Giovanni I am pleased, but not
With your suspicion, that my praises are
Other then what become my ingenuous meaning,
For if I understand, I like your language,
But with it I commend your modest spirit.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It is an honour madam, much above
My youth's ambition, but if I possess
A part of any knowledge you have deigned
To allow, it owes itself unto this school.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: This garden madam, 'tis my academy,
Where gentlemen, and ladies (As yourself,
The first and fairest, durst I call you mistress,)
Enrich my ear, and observation
With harmony of language, which at best
I can but coldly imitate.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Still more courtly!
Why how now Giovanni, you will be
Professor shortly in the art of compliment,
You were best quit the garden, and turn courtier.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Madam, I think upon the court with reverence,
My fate, is to adore it afar off,
It is a glorious landscape, which I look at
As some men with narrow optic glasses
Behold the stars, and wonder at their vast
(Though unknown) habitable worlds of brightness:
But were my eye a nearer judge, and I
Admitted to a clearer knowledge madam
Of the court life, there I might find the truth
Of man's best ideas, and enjoy the happiness,
Now only mine by naked speculation,
I think how there I should throw off my dust
and rise a new creation.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The court
Is much beholding to you Giovanni.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: It is a duty madam I owe truth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A truth in supposition all this while.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I should be sad if any experience should
Betray an error in my faith, and yet
So soft and innocent a trespass, madam,
Might well expect a pardon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Some that have
Freely enjoyed the pleasures, or what else
You so advance in court, have at the last
Been weary, and accused their gay condition,
Nay, changed their state for such an humble life
As you profess, a gardener.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I despise not
What I was born to madam, but I should
Imagine the disease lay in the mind,
Not in the courtier, that would throw away
So spacious a blessing to be servile.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You know not Giovanni your own happiness,
Nor the court sins, the pride and surfeits there
Come not within your circle, there are few
Pursue those noble tracts your fancy aims at,
It is a dangerous sea to launch into,
Both shelves and rocks you see not, ay, and mermaids.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: You mean not women I hope madam?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: O do not by so hard an application
Increase the poet's torment, that first made
That fabulous story to disgrace your sex,
You're firm, and the fair seal of the great maker,
A print next that of angels.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We are bound t'ee
if our cause want a flourish, you have art
To make us show fair.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And you are so,
'Tis malice dares traduce you; or blind ignorance
That throws her strains, which fall off from your figures,
For those which weaker understandings call
Your spots, are ermines, and can such as these
Darlings of heaven, and nature, women, shoot
At court an influence like unlucky planets?
They cannot sure, why you live madam there,
That are enough to prove all praise, a truth,
And by a sweet example make 'em all
Such as you are objects, of love and wonder,
O then how blessed are they that live at court,
With freedom to converse with so much virtue;
As your fair sex embraceth.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Madam I hope you'll pardon my son's rudeness
To hold discourse with your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis a courtesy,
And he talks well to pass away the time,
Exceeding well, but I must to my guardian
The Duke —

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Happiness attend your ladyship.
Now sir what are you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Nay stay, I must talk with you myself,
But first what talk had you with my lady?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: She was pleased to ask some questions.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: You ha' forgotten you're a lewd
And saucy boy, go to, your father spoils you;

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: But if you use me sirrah oth' this fashion
I'll break your pate, I will, the Duke's own son
(My blessing upon him) would not answer me
With I ha' forgotten, I warrant you, but you —

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Why, how now Ursula, what? perpetual clamours?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Nothing unkind to me, she was angry
With your servant Georgio, and threatened to break
His head, away —

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Was it but so? she shall, she shall do that,
With all my heart, and I will break it too.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Nay, than I will be friends with him.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: I won't be compelled to break his head,
And you were twenty husbands; fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: 'Tis such a wasp, but she sha'not wrong thee.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I know she won't sir, she is my mother,
She comes again.

div.stage: Enter Thomazo, Malipiero, Barnardo and Marcello.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: My heart does leap to see you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The Duke's son, and a troop of gallants, but
I always have sore eyes to see one there,
That signior Malipiero, he does owe me
Already forty crowns, and I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Signior Roberto, remember that I owe
You forty crowns.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I never pay till it come to a hundred.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Never pay! it is no matter signior.
I were best be gone before he borrow more,
It is a trick he uses to put on
With his rich clothes, I'll vanish.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Strange this English man appears not?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: I was afraid you had been sick my lord.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I was never sick in my life, but when
I had a fever, or some other infirmity.
I'll call thee nurse still. Giovanni.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: The more's my misfortune.
You are the Duke's son.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: He was never courteous to women.
Here's a gentleman, and they talk of a gentleman,
Now could I weep for joy. I must take my leave sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I must make bold with my nurse.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Blessings upon thy heart, how sweetly he kisses.
Here was a touch for a lady.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Go thy ways,
An admirable twanging lip, pity thou art
A thought too old: ha wagtail!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Alone, be you resolute
When you see me draw, shoot all your points
Into his heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Unless
He be steel-proof, he sha'not boast abroad
Much victory in Venice.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: You pay too much sir for no service.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Here he is.
We were wagering thou wouldst not keep thy promise.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I durst not make that forfeit of your grace,
I most consult my own, when I am careful
To wait upon your honour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I was not willing to engage myself
Abroad, lest I might trespass on your patience.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Walk a turn,
And then to a bona roba.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Giovanni!
Thy spade, and hold my cloak.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I have 'Great mind to dig now, dost think I cannot
Handle a spade, I'll make a bed with my gentlemen now
For a hundred ducats.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis a base employment,
Fit for such a drudge as Giovanni.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A drudge? I said, d'ye scorn your little dunghill breed?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You were best be his champion.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Are you good at that?
I do not love to wear my doublet pinked.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.stage: Giovanni recovers a sword, having first used his spade to side with the Englishman: Bernardo having lost his weapon flies.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I am no drudge you'll find
To be commanded sir, you painted flies,
And only fit for trouts.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Lost our advantage? is Thomazo fled?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And Bernardo, we were best retire, that Gardiner
Will stick me into ground, else for a plant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They are not worth it Giovanni, so
I heard you named.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou hast relieved, and saved my life, I find
Their base conspiracy, what shall I pay
Thy forward rescue?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: 'Tis but what I owe
To justice, with the expense of blood and life
To prevent treachery, reward I have
Received i'th act, if I have done you service.
But 'twas your innocence that made such haste
To your own valour, not my sword preserved you.
I am young, and never taught to fight.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I prithee
Accept this trifle, buy a sword, and wear it,
Thou hast deserved to thrive a nobler way
Than thy condition shows.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Though some would call
This bounty, urge it not to my disgrace,
I scorn to sell the motion of my arm!
I fear you are not safe yet, there may be
Danger in following them, and it grows dark.
Have patience while I fetch a key, that shall
Befriend you with a private way.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou'rt noble,
Though I am careless where the terms of honour
Engage my life, 'tis wisdom not to lose it
Upon their base revenge, but I must study
Some other payment for this young man's courage.
Howe'er his body suffer in a cloud,
His spirit's not obscure, but brave, and active.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: If my intelligence fail not, he must be
Here still. This evening hath put on a vizard
to conspire with me, there he walks, surprise him.

div.stage: They seize upon him, bind his arms and feet, and blind him with a bag.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: If you be loud, we'll strange you.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: We ha' done sir, is he for the river now?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: These show like officers,
Alas he's apprehended on their base
Complaint, I cannot help; thy cause and innocence
Must now befriend thee! base world! yet I may
Injure, the parts abroad; 'tis only Venice
Is sick with these distempers, then ▪ I'll leave it,
And instantly pursue some other fate
I'th wars, it may cure something too within me,
That is denied all remedy at home,
Somebody's for their physic, are designed
To change of air, I'll try't upon my mind.

div.head: Act. 3.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Not this Englishman to be found?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: He's not above ground
Where I could suspect him in the city —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let him go, may be his haste toppled him
Into the river, and we may eat his nose
In the next haddock.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Twas something like a will,
To keep your skin from eyelet-holes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I grant you,
What had I to do to bring up a fashion?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We might ha'gone a sure and nearer way
To ha' killed him in a right line with a bullet,
But let him go, so he quit Venice any way.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: He would spoil our mirth, but I much wonder
Bernardo is not come yet, whom I sent
Ambassador for money to the merchants.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nor Marcello, whom I employed to the same end,
To my most costive uncle for some goldfinches.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why should the state have an exchequer, and
We want?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: For pious uses too, to drink their health;
And see the commonwealth go round
In mutual commerce of mirth and spirit,
Which phlegm and usury hath almost stifled,
Sobriety and long gowns spoil the city.
'Tis we would keep the body politic
From stinking, ulcered with long obligations,
And notaries, which now stuff the Rialto,
And poison honest natures, that would else
Live freely, and be drunk at their own charge.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I would make new laws, and I were Duke of Venice.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We would not sit i'th chimney corner then,
And sing like crickets.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: We would roar like trumpets,
And deaf the senators with, give us your moneys —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Theirs? give us our own, their states, their wives,
And wardrobes Scanderbeg.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And their pretty daughters,
My valiant Turk, who should feed high of purpose —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To keep the wanton blood in titillations.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: It should be a law, no maid should be in fashion.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes let 'em be in fashion, but not hold.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Not after fourteen be it then enacted.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We would banish all the advocates that refused
To pimp, and prove it civil law.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No scribe should dare to show his ears in our dominions

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hang 'em, they are labels of the law, and stink,
Worse than a fish-shambles in Lent. No Jew
Should turn a christian upon peril of
A confiscation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The slaves are rich,
To turn 'em Christians were to spoil their conscience,
And make 'em hide their money, 'tis less evil
In state to cherish Jews, than Christian usurers.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I will have every citizen a Jew then.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: We have built no seraglio yet.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That's true,
What think you of the universities?
Would not they serve?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O excellent,
They have several schools for several games.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And scaffolds
For the spectators when we keep our acts.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The college rends would find the wench's petticoats,
And the revenues of a score of abbeys
Well stripped; would serve to roll 'em in clean linen,
And keep the toys in diet.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Excellent!
But when we have converted to the use
The monasteries, where shall we bestow
The friars, and the thin religious men?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You may
Keep them with little charge, water is all
The blessing their poor thirst requires, and tailor's
Won't be troubled for new clothes, a hair shirt
Will outwear a copyhold, and warm 4 lives,
Or if you think 'em troublesome, it is
A fair pretence to send 'em to some wild
Country to plant the faith, and teach the infidels
A way to heaven, for which they may be burnt
Or hanged, and there's an end o'th honest men.
There be a thousand ways to quiet them.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: My admirable counsellor, thou shouldst be
My supreme officer to see justice done.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You cannot honour men of worth too much.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: We'll ha' the bridges all pulled down, and made
Of silver.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Dross! Gold is our orient metal.
Here is Benardo, welcome, where's the money?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Not a gazet: the merchants are all sullen,
And say you owe too much already.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: These are dogbolts.
'Tis time we had new laws and they won't trust.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: But we must build
No golden bridges at this rate with sunbeams.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: They were best content themselves with honest stone,
Hard as the heart of your ungodly merchants.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Prithee let's leave our dream of frighting sailors,
And say, what hope hast thou of getting money
for this day's mirth?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Some hope there is, if my uncle have but faith
Enough, to credit what I never mean,
Thrift and submission, and holy matters;
'Tis all the ways are left to cozen him
And creep into his nature, I have pawned
All my religion that I'll turn friar.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hast pawned thy religion, much good do him,
Let him take the forfeit, so he send thee money —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: For present use, and howl, and hang himself.
I care not — o — here's Marcello.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He does commend him to you, and with it this —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I knew 'twould take, his tender conscience

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This halter — he has tied the knot himself,
And says next the philosopher's stone, he knows not
What thing of nobler value to present you:
And rather than you should delay for want
Of a convenient — you know what, you should
Once more peruse his orchard, there's one tree
He would have bear no other fruit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I thank him.
For his fine noose, would I had his neck in't,
The devil should not conjure him from this circle.
Is this the end of all?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I prithee try how it will hold — d'ye hear
Let's lay our heads together. Which of you
Is best acquainted with the Turk?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The great and mighty sultan, the grand signior.
Or have you but a Christian correspondence
With any of his heathen officers.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No rogue that lies perdieu here for intelligence?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I would make a bargain with him now and sell
This city to the pagan instantly.
Venice is a jewel, a rich pendant;
Would hang rarely at the great Turks ear.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Or at one horn of his half moon.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I would betray if I knew how, the state
Or any thing for half a hundred ducats
To make one merry night, though after I
Were broke upon a wheel, or set upright
To peep through a cleft tree like a polecat
In the high way — no money from the mongrels?
Well if I live. I will to Amsterdam,
And add another schism to the two hundred
Fourscore and odd;
I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To cry down all things
That hang on wit, truth, or religion.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Come, thou art passionate, is there no trick?
No lewd device? let me see? — I have thought
Away to raise us my dear Tully, a project
Shall raise us, or I'll venture —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: My neck
For hanging is the end of my device,
Unless I thrive in't: go to the rendezvous,
to Rosabella's on the grand cavale,
Kiss her and call for wines, my bullyrookes,
A dish of dainty fiddlers to curvet too,
And drink a health that I may prosper, tumble
And shake the house, I'll fetch you off.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No more words, cannot you be gone, be drunk,
And leave me to the reckoning, I'll return
With Indian spoils like Alexander.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Spoken
Like a true Macedonian, we are gone.
He's right, and may in time, and our good breeding
Be brought to something, may deserve the galleys.
Follow your leaders Myrmidons.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: But will you venture signior Giovanni
Your body to the wars indeed?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: And leave me to be lost, or thrown away
Among the weeds here!

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yes, and come hopping home upon one leg.
Will all my pay then buy a handsome halter
To hang my arm in, if it be but maimed,
Yet I endure a battle every day,
My mistress hath a mouth carries whole cannon;
And if you took that engine to the wars,
You would find it do rare service.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Her tongue;
Make her but angry, and you'll need no more
Artillery to scour them with a breach.
What spoil her breath would make in a market place?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Be less satirical;
I must not hear this, she is my mother.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: She is my mistress, and that's worse, but I'm resolved,
I'll to the wars w'e, do not tell her on't,
My prenticeship is worse than killing there.
My hand, I'll w'ee.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: In the mean time buy ye a sword, and belt,
And what is fit.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: No more, I'll be a soldier;
And kill according to my pay, this will
Suffice to vamp my body, I may rise
If I grow rich in valour, that will do't,
Money and a tilting feather make a captain.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: There is no other way to quiet the
Afflictions here, beside 'tis honourable,
And war a glorious mistress.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I know madam you may break his resolution,
If you be pleased, you may command; he's here.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Blessings attend your ladyship.
I'll wait for the success.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How now Giovanni,
What with a sword, you were not used to appear
Thus armed, your weapon is a spade I take it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It did become my late profession madam;
But I am changed.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It is a title madam will much grace me,
And with the best collection of my thoughts
I have ambition to the war.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: O 'tis a brave profession, and rewards
all loss we meet with double weight in glory,
A calling princes still are proud to own,
And some do willingly forget their crowns
To be commanded, 'tis the spring of all
We here entitle fame to, emperors
And all degrees of honours, owing all
Their names to this employment, in her vast
And circular embraces holding Kings,
And making them; and yet so kind as not
To exclude such private things as I, who may
Learn and commence in her great arts. My life
Hath been too useless to myself and country,
'Tis time I should employ it to deserve
A name within their registry, that bring
The wealth, the harvest home of well bought honour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It is an active time I must confess,
And the unhappy scene of war too near us
But that it should inflame you on the sudden
To leave a calm, and secure life, is more
Than commonly it works on men of your
Birth, and condition, besides I hear
Your father is not willing you should leave him,
To engage yourself in such apparent danger.
Here you will forfeit your obedience
Unless you stay.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I cannot despair madam
Of his consent, and if by my own strength
Of reason I incline him not, it was
In my ambition to address my humble
Suit to your ladyship to gain it for me,
At worst it is no breach of duty madam,
If I prefer my country and her cause
Now bleeding, before any formal ties
Of nature to a soft indulgent father.
For danger, let pale souls consider it,
It is beneath my fears.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yet I can see
Through all this resolution iovanni?
'Tis something else hath wrought this violent change,
Pray let me be of counsel with your thoughts,
And know the serious motive, come be clear,
I am no enemy, and can assist
Where I allow the cause.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You may be angry
Madam, and chide it as a saucy pride
In me to name, or look at honour, nor
Can I but know what small addition
Is my unskilful arm to aid a country.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I may therefore justly suspect, there is
Something of other force that moves you to
The wars, enlarge my knowledge with the secret.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: At this command I open my heart, madam,
I must confess there is another cause
Which I dare not in obedience
Obscure, since you will call it forth, and yet
I know you will laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It would ill
Become my breeding Giovanni.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Then,
Know madam, I'm in love.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: With one I dare not name, she's so much
Above my birth and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I commend
Your flight, but does she know it?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I durst never
Appear with so much boldness to discover
My hearts so great ambition, 'tis here still,
A strange and busy guest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And you think absence
May cure this wound.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I may presume,
You think she's fair.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I dare as soon question your beauty madam,
The only ornament, and star of Venice,
Pardon the bold comparison, yet there is
Something in you resembles my great mistress
She blushes —
Such very beams disperseth her bright eye
Powerful to restore decrepit nature,
But when she frowns, and changes from her sweet
Aspect (As in my fears I see you now
Offended at my boldness) she does blast
Poor Giovanni thus, and thus I wither
At heart, and wish myself a thing lost in
My own forgotten dust, but it's not possible
At last (If any stars bless but high thoughts)
By some desert in war, and deeds of honour.)
(For mean as I, have raised themselves to empire)
That she without a blush to stain her cheek
May own me for a servant — I am lost
In wand'ring apprehensions.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Poor Giovanni,
I pity thee, but cannot cure — I like
Thy aspiring thoughts, and to this last of love,
Allow the wars a noble remedy.
I have argued against your sons resolve, but find
His reasons overcome my weak dispute.
And I must counsel you to allow 'em too.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Nay, I was never much against it madam.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: She loves him not, but does your ladyship
Think fitting, he should go?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, yes 'tis honourable;
And to encourage his forward spirit,
The general is my kinsman Giovanni,
what favours he can do you, you shall have
My letters to entreat, and at my charge
You shall be furnished like a gentleman,
Attend me at my lodgings.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You bind all
My services; why this will make a show yet.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Nay, then take my consent and blessing too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Bellaura, I must speak to you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You have my purpose, and return me clearly
How he bestows himself, and what society
Withdraws him from his duty thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall
With my best care.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I fear that Malipiero,[with Bellaura]
But let me find your diligence: Bellaura.

div.stage: The scene adorned with pictures amongst the rest Claudiana's enter bravoes with the Englishman, they unbind him and exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am all wonder: shall I trust my senses.
A fair and pleasant gallery; was I
Surprised for this? or do I dream, I did
Expect the end of my conveyance should
Have been more fatal,
No tract appears, or sign of those that brought me,
The place is rich in ornament, sure these
Are pictures, all things silent as the images,
And yet these speak, some do inhabit here,
This room was not ordained only for air
And shadows, 'tis some flattering prologue to
My death, some plot to second the affront
of Malipiero with more scorn to ruin me.
sp.stage: Enter Cornari with a case of pistols.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That posture and presentment
Promise no great assurance, yet there's something
Within that noble frame would tempt me to
Believe thou art.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A black murderer.
Point not thy horrid messengers of death
Upon a man disarmed, my bosom is
No proof against those fiery executioners.
How came I to deserve from thee unknown
So black a purpose, as thy looks present me?
I never saw thy face, nor am I conscious
Of any act, in whose revenge, thou hast
Put on this horror, let me know my guilt
Before I die, although I never lived
At that poor rate to fear a noble death;
Yet unprepared, and thus to die, doth something
Stagger my soul, and weaken my resolve
To meet thy execution, thou hast
Too good a face to be a mercenary
Cutthroat, and Malipiero would become
The hangman's office better.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You believe then,
How easily I can command your destiny,
I have no plot with any Malipiero,
And thus remove thy fears

div.stage: He carries in the pistols and returns.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You're still within
My power, but call yourself my guest, not prisoner,
And if you be not dangerous to yourself
nothing is meant but safety here and honour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This does amaze me more; but do Italians
Compel men to receive their courtesies?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I must not give you reasons; yet for your
Surprise, you may receive a timely knowledge
And not repent. I am a gentleman,
And by that name secure thee, if you can
Fancy a peace with this restraint, 'tis none
But something that may please you above freedom,
If your unruly thoughts tempt a resistance,
Death is let in, at every thing you look at.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll leave my wonder and believe, what now
Must I obey?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How do you like this gallery?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Your eyes are yet too careless, pray examine 'em.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Have your eyes ever
Met with a substance that might reflect
On any of these shadow's sir in Venice?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Look a little better, is there nothing
Of more than common curiosity,
In any of these beauties.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have seen
Fair ones, what should this mean?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But pray tell me,
Of these (Which some have praised for handsomeness)
Which doth affect you most? I guess you have
By frequent view, and the converse with ladies
arrived at excellent judgement:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I did not
Expect this dialogue, yet I'll be free,
I profess stranger to 'em all, but this[pointing to Claudiana]
I should elect the fairest and most worthy
A masculine embrace. I build upon
The promise of your honour, I should else
Be nice in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You are just,
And I prefer that too, what will you say
To call that lady mistress, and enjoy her?
She's noble to my knowledge, but enough
At this time. I must pray your kind excuse
If (Whilst) you walk into this room

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Which is designed your lodging, I become
Your jailor, and make sure this gallery
Till my return; be constant to your temper,
There shall be nothing wanting to procure
You safe, and pleasant hours.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Distrust falls off.
I will expect to find you noble, though
My faith bind not to all, and enter.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: So.
I tread a maze too, but must not resign
My office, till I perfect my design

div.stage: Enter Malipiero with Rosabella dancing, [dance] Bernardo, Marcello.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Excellent
They move as they had nothing else but soul.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: So, drink, we are not merry, here's a health
To my hen sparrow.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What Rosabella's health? before the states —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hang states, and commonwealths we will be emperors;
And laugh, and drink away whole provinces.
Shall we not didapper?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What you please, but will signior
Thomazo be here presently, and bring —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The golden fleece, thou lady Guinever,
And he shall mount thy little modesty,
And ride like Agamemnon, and shall pay for't,
While we, like valiant Greeks in lusty wine,
Drench the remembrance that we are mortal,
More wine, my everlasting marmoset.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Brave Malipiero still! our grand signior's health,[drinks]
Signior Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Let it come squirrels,
And then a song my pretty Rosabella,
Which of the senators were here last night
To court thee with a draught of dissolved pearl?
Be supple to thy friends, and let thy men
Of state, who hide their warped legs in long gowns,
And keep their wisdom warm in furs like agues,
Most grave and serious follies, wait, and want
The knowledge of thy fiddle, my dear Dowsabel.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What hath advanced your brain thus Malipiero?
You were not wont to talk at such a height,
There is some mighty fortune dropping, is
Your uncle sick, whose heir you hope to be?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hang uncles, there's a damp in's very name.
Wine, or I sink, — so now thy song, come sit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Nay you shall enter, gentlemen, my friend, salute him, Malipiero, he is one
may do us service.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That were a jest, you shall stay by this hand,
Who has the wine, drink to my noble friend,
Whilst I embrace my Queen of Carthage.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I have seen this gentleman wait near your father.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Right in his bedchamber, a sober coxcomb,
We met by chance, let's make him drunk, I have
The brave devices here boy.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Good: you're welcome,
Fill me a tun of wine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: It is too too little for a friend.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: They'll drown me, here's a precious knot

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I hug thee Cleopatra, gentlemen,
Am not I behind half a score glasses, fill,
Come charge me home, I'll take it here

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: What will become of me? they mean to drench
Me for the sullens, I am like to have
A very fine time, and employment here.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let it be as rich as the Egyptian Queen
Made for mark Anthony; in the mean time
What limb of wantonness have you ready for
My noble friend here, get him a fine flesh saddle,
Or where's thy mother, now I think upon't,
He loves to ride upon a pad.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O by all means signior.
He shall go to the price of any ladyware.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Who I? alas my tilting days are done, nay, nay, then
I'll drink w'ee gentlemen, but I cannot tumble

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: No lady beware for me sweet mistress,
I blush to say I cannot mount at this time.
Would I were off again, polecats for me?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And how, and how show things?
Is't fit we want to revel, while my father
Has these toys idle, we grope in the dark
And lose our way, while such bright stars as these
May light us to a wench?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: There is no conscience in't.
But what shall we do with 'em? there's a lustre
Hath struck me into a flame.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Drink half, and tumble out the rest
In featherbeds.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Stay, sir,
She never can disburse to half their value,
Beside I know their sly and costive natures.
I am acquainted with a Jew, are we
All faithful? are there no traitors here?
I am acquainted with a Jew shall furnish you
To purpose, and transport these, where they sha'not
Betray from whence they came: trust her? 'tis dangerous,
Besides the scanting of your mirth, by a
Penurious son, give me the cabinet —
You're sure all these are friends, and will say nothing?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I warrant thee; what luck had I to meet him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He's one of us, make haste, a mighty sum.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: I'll bring a storm of ducats instantly.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You need not spend the total here, I have use
for forty of those ducats.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: These gentlemen are out of figleaves too.
Some fresher robes would show well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: They shall have
New skins my Holofernes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That's I, I understand the metaphor.
It shall have law, o for some trumpets now.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Tantarra rara boys, outroar the winds
And drink the sun into eclipse, hang miching,
But where's my wanton pinnace?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Boarded by.
Some man of war by this time.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My top and top gallant gone? ha! are there pirates
Upon these ghosts; give fire upon the water-rats,
And shoot pell-mell , fight as a whirlwind flings,
Disordering all, what man of menaces
Dare look awry upon my catamountain?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Not I: now he's got rampant, he'll kill somebody .

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You must not be affrighted, tother lift
And be a giant eke, and talk of terrors
With words Olympus high.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Suppose thou wert my uncle now, come hither,
Hold thy head fair, that I may whip it off.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mine's nothing like, Bernardo has been taken
for your uncle signior.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How dare you be like
The rogue my uncle sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I sir? 'tis
Signior Thomazo that he means, and see
For very fear his head falls off
sp.stage: Thomazo was drinking and here sets down the bottle.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Reach it me,
I'll drink a health, then in his skull.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Who talks of me, who dares mention
A thought of me? where be the dainty ducats?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: The money's coming sir, six men are laden,
And will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thou shalt drink
A health, kneel venerable sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Be humble,
Thou man of Malligo, or thou diest

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He has a very good meaning, never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: That you shall pledge, or forfeit your sconce to me,
None shall have the honour to pledge this health,
But this whey bearded signior.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Now do my brains tumble, tumble, tumble —

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Give it him,
And drink it with devotion as I did.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I long to see these double, double — hickets
But where's the cockatrice, this whirligig?
Is my head fast?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The screw is firm, suspect not.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: I dare not pray nor ask forgiveness here.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Do not my brains now turn upon the toe.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Do you hear my doughty signior Thomazo,
Wouldst you kill the Duke, your graceless father now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You shall let him into the chamber one night,
Where he shall strangle him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Or I can play upon his windpipe rarely.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We'll see (D'ye mark) some corner of the palace
A fire, at the same time, and in that hurry
Break into the treasury, take what we think fit,
And steal away by sea into another country.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Most admirably contrived; the men are come.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Plots, ambuscadoes, are these your Jew tricks.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I'll wait till you have slept away your surfeit,
Here in the house.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Which is the Jew of all these?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: We are cheated by a court-nap.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: My friend, are you the Jew? where be the jewels.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Truth is, I have sent the jewels to your father,
And he will lend no money.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But must we go to prison?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I'll to prison with 'em spite o'your teeth.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Not, till you have slept, this way.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A rescue.
We are snatched up for traitors, we are betrayed,
And going to prison.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Who pays for the wine and banquet?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why any living body, that has a scruple
In's conscience, for the loss of thy dear comfits,
And caraways, away, lead me ye rogues.
I'll not march else, and let us make a show,
My fine officious rascals, on afore,
I follow in fit state, so farewell firelock.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Undoing is thy trade,
March on I say.

div.head: Act. 4.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Your pleasure sir; you did command my presence.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Are you come? you and I must not be
Interrupted Claudiana.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Why do you shut your chamber?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: We must be private.
How does my life?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Well sir, if you be so.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I have a suit to thee, my best Caudiana.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: To me? it must be granted.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: That's well said,
But 'tis a business (Sweet) of mighty consequence,
More precious than my life.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Goodness forbid
I should not give obedience to the least
Of your commands, but when your life requires
My service, I should chide my heart, and thoughts
Unless they put on wings to show their duty.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis a business sweet will speak thy love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou knowest how many years since the priest tied
Our holy knot, with what religious flowing
Of chaste and noble love our hearts have met,
How many blessings have I summed in thee,
And but in thee, for unto this, heaven gave not
(That which indeed doth crown all marriage,)
Children, thou hast been fruitful Claudiana
In all that's good, but only fruitfulness;
And when I think who in my want of that
Great blessing of thy womb, must be my heir,
A base and impious villain, to possess
And riot in my spacious fortunes, I
Forget that other happiness in thy person,
And let in a vexation to consume me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I know not what to fear, it is heaven's will
And not my fault.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O no, the fault is mine,
All mine Claudiana, for thou art not barren
'Tis I, a man prodigious and mulcted
By nature, without faculty of man
To make our marriage happy, and preserve
This fair; this lovely figure, be at peace
And let me blush, a thing not worth the love
Of such a bounteous sweetness.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Let me fall
Beneath that which sustains me, ere I take
In a belief, that will destroy my peace,
Not in the apprehension of what
You frame to accuse yourself, but in fear
My honour is betrayed to your suspicion;
O kill me sir, before I lose your thought,
Your noble thought.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Rise, with thy tears I kiss
Away thy tremblings; I suspect thy honour?
My heart will want faith to believe an angel,
that should traduce thy fair name, thou art chaste
As the white down of heaven, whose feathers play
Upon the wings of a cold winter's gale,
Trembling with fear to touch the impurer earth.
How are the roses frighted in thy cheeks
To paleness, weeping out of transparent dew:
When a loose story is but named? thou art
The miracle of a chaste wife, from which fair
Original, drawn out by heavens own hand,
To have had one copy, I had write perfection
To all my wishes here, but 'tis denied me,
Nor do I mock thee with a fable, while
I miserably complain, convinced, and lost
In my own masculine defect; but yet
I love thee Claudiana, dost not think so?
And after so much injury, I bring
Not my repentance only, but a just
And noble satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You oppress
My senses with the weight of new amazement.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I must be clear, thou must embrace another —
Another in my bed, whom from the world
I have made choice to know thee, be not frighted
This way is left, and this alone to recompense
My want, and make both happy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I embrace
Another in your bed?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Dost think I would
Attempt, or wish thee to't, without a care
In every circumstance to both our fames?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Fame? are you master of your reason? dare you
Provoke heaven thus?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Heaven only shall be witness,
Whose secrecy I'll trust, but not another's.
Beside the principal agent, to get heaven.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes, and thy husband,
A just one to thy memory, that would
Cancel his faith, rather than be a strict
Idolater of words, and severe laws,
To the destroying of so sweet a figure;
I would not have thee fly like birds i'th air,
Or ships that leave no tract, to say here was,
So rich a blessing, rather like a plant
Should root, and grow, and bloom, and bear for ever.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Be wise and meet my wishes, 'tis my love
That hath overcome all nice considerings
To do thee justice. Nor will I intrude
Upon thy bosom one shall be unwelcome,
He's honourably born, of comely person,
But has a soul adds glory to 'em both,
A boy from him, born to my name and fortunes
Leaves not another wealth to my ambition.
To raise thy free consent my Claudiana,
'Tis he, whom thou dost think worth thy own praise,
The gentleman victorious for his parts,
So late in Venice, the English cavalier.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: To be short,
I have surprised his person for this use,
He hath been many days an obscure guest
Within the lodgings next the garden, for
I must confess I have had strugglings in
My nature, and have sat in council 'gainst
Myself sometime, touching this great affair,
But I have answered every thing opposed it,
And took this time to acquaint thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I will,
And him too, if ye mingle not and make
the project as I cast it, be not obstinate,
Why, he shall ne'er discover who thou act,
If thou be faithful to thyself, thou mayst
Pretend thyself some pleasant bona roba.
Dr take what name, and shape thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There's none
Can hide my shame, or wash the stain away:

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What shame or stain is in't when it is kept
A secret darker than the book of destiny
From mankind?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Am I practised in those arts?
Of sin that he should take me for a courtesan?
Nay, rather let me be known your wife,
It will oblige him more to use me well,
And thank your loving pains that brought me to him.
If I must be a whore, and you a —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay, and I a — what? I bleed within me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: This key will make the chamber free, I follow.
Consider sir, I'm else undone for ever

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why if he know me for her husband, 'tis
Without a name, I can secure my honour,
And send him quickly to eternal silence.
I'm resolved they must obey, proceed,
A little blood will wash away this deed.

div.stage: Enter Duke, senators, attendants, letters upon a table.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Our city drooping with the wounds so late
Received, is now to study with what joys
To entertain so great a victory.
Treviso is returned to our obedience,
Almost without a loss, how many fell
On the adverse part, those papers signify,
And must enlarge our triumph: but is't not
Strange what our general writes of Giovanni,
whose spirit he admires, and forward valour,
Referring to his bold attempt, our conquest,
That he advanced his head and sword first on
The enemy's walls, which inflamed our army
To second him with courage, and that after
With his own hands he slew their general,
Whose fall shot death and trembling through their army.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He is by direction of our general
Now marching hither, to his only conduct.
The captives are remitted, and his act
By us to be considered, but we have
Sent order for the placing of his prisoners
Securely, and commanded he should here
Attend our pleasure

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The same, whose early valour takes away
The prejudice of humble birth, and ought
To be encouraged nobly.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Is't possible the gardiner's son should so
Behave himself in war,
He will deserve some honour for't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why may not
Our power dispense, and though his low condition
By our rule exempt him (For his gallant service
Done) now create him gentleman of Venice,
With a noble pension from our treasury
To bear his title up?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: We give it strangers,
Whose birth we not examine,
He deserves it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Let him receive no favour
for his relation to me, but take
His place and punishment with the rest, away
I cast him from my thought.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Why comes not
Our general himself?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Reasons of war
May yet compel his stay, he's to repair
Some breaches which our soldiers made, and wisely
By some new fortification, secure
The town if the enemy should reinforce.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Hath he disposed
By our direction those prisoners were
Sent by our general?

sp.speaker: Attendant
sp.p: He hath and please your excellency.

div.stage: Enter Giovanni plumed and brave Georgio his servant

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: All health and honour to the Duke and senate.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We thank thee Giovanni, and will spare
Your trouble to 'Relate what we have gained
I'th war; our general writes how much our Venice
Doth owe to you, whose maiden yet bold valour,
Hath wrought our safety, and suppressed the late
Insolent genoese.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your bounty makes
That mine, which I want merit sir to challenge,
But if my will to serve my country (For
Beside that name and warm desires, I dare
Call nothing mine) you're pleased to accept and cherish
A young man's duty, you will teach me in
The next employment to deserve indeed.
Till when, you lose not, to have built upon
This humble pile, a monument of your goodness,
to tell the world, although misplaced on me,
You love a growing virtue.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This Giovanni?
His words taste more of courtier than the garden.
To show we understand, and to that knowledge
Have will to recompense the desert, Giovanni
The senate bids you ask, what in your power
Your thought can aim at, to reward your service,
And you shall soon possess it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Ask, ask quickly,
A hundred thousand double double ducats.
'Twil serve us both, do't, beggars must be impudent.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Now you destroy what else might live to serve you,
This grace will make me nothing, when I call
My airy worth to balance, keep those glorious
Rewards for men born, and brought up in honour?
That may be great and able columns to
Your ever envied state; alas I rise
Like a thin reed beneath this commonwealth,
Whose weight, an Atlas must sustain like heaven,
This favour is too mighty, and if you
Command me, ask a just reward, 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: You had as good ha' said nothing, I blush for you,
You know many soldiers
So modest, to refuse pay, or preferment?
They cannot have it sometimes, after many
Petitions to the state, and now their minds
Are soluble and apt to pour out favours,
You to be so maidenly —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: May I credit
With pardon of your wisdoms, that you mean
To encourage thus the low born Giovanni?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Now he makes question of their honesty too,
O simple soldier.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We look not at thy root, but at thy blossom,
And as a preserver of our country
We offer up a gratitude, consult
With thy best judgement, (Though beside this act
Of his abroad) I can give no account[aside]
Why I should love this young man, or prefer him,
I know not by what mystery, I have
Had thoughts to wish him more than common fortune,
And this occasion of his merit offered.
I will pursue.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Do as I counsel you, and remember, I
Have left my fortunes, and my trade to serve you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Call it not pride if I be willing to
Believe your excellence, that I have done
Something your goodness prompts you to reward,
And the grave senate, I have thought.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Now do I expect to be half a senator at least.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And since you raise my act to such a merit,
I will not ask a thing too much beneath it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And shame your bounty; yet I may fear
You will not grant —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: I look at no reward of gold.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How's that? he's out on's part.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I know not,
By what fate I contemn it, nor at titles
Of honour, or command, or what can trench
On state or wealth.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I thank ye heartily,
I must to dig again.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Employ such gifts,
To pay some slight, and mercenary souls,
That make their end of good, reward, and not
itself, but since you have imposed I should
Make choice of somewhat know my ambition aims —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It is too great a happiness, but I now
Consider I have prattled to the wind,
What I desire is not within your power,
And what you may command, not in my wishes,
For I would ask Bellaura: can you make
Me fit for such a blessing? no, you cannot,
Unless I were unborn, and should again
Come forth, not Giovanni, but the son
Of some bright name, and this world-taking honour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam I dare not
Be seen, if you prevail, I shall attend,
And put his mercy into act.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I have a suit to your highness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: About your son, whom men to your dishonour
Lead like some base offender.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I must speak
The cause into your ear.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I was too blame
To mention her so public, but my heart
Grew sick with silence, and their proposition
To ask what I desired most, prevailed
Against my reason:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Leave him to me, Bellaura.
Do you observe that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.l: 'Tis Giovanni.
He does become the soldier.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He has done wonders
Abroad, and quit our gratitude, to be
Only by you rewarded, can you love him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How have I lost myself, since I became
Your charge, a legacy bequeathed your care
By my dead father, the late Duke of Venice,
That you should think I can descend with such
Forgetfulness of myself, my birth or fortunes
To place my love on one so poorly born.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You blush. Bael. 'tis anger in my blood to hear him named. [to Giovanni]
You pay me coursely for my charity.
Learn modesty hereafter to be grateful.
I ha' done w'ye sir

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Do you here the tit? be wise,
And look at ready money, 'tis a better
Commodity than any lady in Christendom;

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Pray dismiss,
And pardon Giovanni. I am satisfied.
For your own honour let not my ambition
Be told abroad, I'll check and punish my
Aspiring thoughts hereafter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You have leave,
Come gentlemen,
He is in love.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What shall become of us now by your folly?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: We'll to the garden George, and there begin
Another growth, for what we have's despised.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I knew I should return to my dear dunghill.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I prithee see the armour which Bellaura
Bestowed on me, brought home.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Your armour? yes
We might have worn soft natured silk, and you had
Been ruled by me, a pox of love for my part,
