'Tis good for nothing, but to make things dear.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I'll be revenged upon my stars, that made
me poor, and die forgotten in my shade

div.stage: A table prepared, two tapers. Enter Florelli.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I find no great devotion in this
Monastic life, the maior domo promised
A mistress here of that complexion,
But I like not this solitude,
And tedious expectations,
I shall ne'er do things handsomely,
Give me freedom and fair play,
And turn me to a harpy, but to be thus
Compelled to an embrace (For that's the meaning
Of my sly signior, if it be not worse)
Fed high to encounter with an Amazon,
I know not? 'tis not well, nor conscionable
In my opinion: I hear some busy
About the lock.
My jailor? What now fellows?
Sir, if I must ha' my throat cut, as much
Better I do not hope, though I deserve not
That bounty from your hands, I live so dully,
I would request you set a time, an't be
A day or two, to pray and think of matters,
And then turn me lose to the other world!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He sha'not see my blushes, I must pity
Thee Claudiana, but my stubborn fate
Will have it so, it is to make thee live
Although we both must suffer, and I like
A father thus, whose child at play upon
A river's bank, is fallen into the stream,
Leap in, and hazard all to save a little,
But I must on

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Amazement circles me,
Such wonders are not read in every marriage,
What shall I do? madness to question it.
I must resolve or die? since there's no help,
'Tis something if she be but like that face
To comfort my proceeding.

div.stage: Enter Cornari leading his wife veiled.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Behold, and take as lent this treasure from me,
I must expect it back again with interest.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The door is fast again, here is a precedent
For husbands that want heirs to their estate.
A goodly person. Please you lady, to
Unveil; a rich and most inviting beauty. [she unveils]
I am all flame, shall I take boldness, after
My duty paid your white hand, to aspire
And touch your lip — now could I wish to dwell ▪ here. [he kisses]
Can you read lady? She takes the paper and turns.
She turns away her face. I hope my signior
Has taken pains to bring her to the business,
And not left me to break her: can she speak?
Those lines (I know not how you like 'em madam)
Were none of my invention, the character,
I guess to be your husbands. I am here
A prisoner to his will, to which unless
You give obedience, I have taken leave
Of day for ever, destined by his vow
To an eternal shade. Exit Claudiana.
She leads the way;
Conscience be calm, no grumblings now of piety.

div.head: Act. 5.
div.stage: Giovanni. The pieces of armour hung upon several trees Roberto, Ursula.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: These were the excellent Bellaura's gift,
Of no use now to me, but to keep fresh
the memory of my dreams and that I loved her.
I see how passion did blind my reason,
And my prodigious hopes vanished to air
Have left me to contemplate my own vanity.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I know not, but if I may credit Georgio
That did wait on thee to the senate, thou
Hast lost an opportunity, that might
Have made us all Clarissimo's Giovanni.
I might have kept my reverend mules, and had
My crupper worshipped by the plebeians,
And Ursula here been madam heaven knows what,
And did you wisely to refuse?

sp.speaker: Ur.
sp.l: Nay, nay I know
He was not born to do us good, not stoop
To take preferment from the Duke and senate?

sp.speaker: Ur.
sp.p: He learned it not from me.

sp.speaker: Ur.
sp.l: You will be always taking his part against me,
But I know, what I know, and that's a secret,
Here comes the tother dunderhead.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: The armour is hung up already, this
We must all come to.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Master look here.
If you had but this hole to put your head in,
It would be a great preservative to your hearing,
And keep out all the noise, of my dame's culverin,
Within this fortification well locked up.
You would think her loudest scolding a mere whisper.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: What's that you talk of your dame sirrah?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: O dame, I have news for you.

sp.speaker: Urs
sp.p: For me? what is't? whom does your news concern?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: One that you love with all your heart.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Knave? call your word in, and eat it, I'll advise,
You may fare worse: you do not hear the news then?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: I shall when you'll find utterance.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: The news —
We are all of one religion?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Every thing is not to be talked on.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: So it seems by your concealment.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: There's a gentleman, and you talk of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: What of Thomazo? now am I longing.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I heard, as I came hither —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That he is to lose his head mistress —

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Now a thousand blisters upon that tongue.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: But you do not know for what, mistress there's it,
You are so angry still at half a business.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: For what is he to suffer? o my heart!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You ha' not patience, to hear a story out.

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: High treason said he? that's a shrewd business.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I told you but in good will, because I knew
You loved him. I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Passion oh my dear heart! I'll to the Duke
Myself, and beg his pardon.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You'll make
yourself a party in the treason, will you?
You'll beg his pardon, you'll beg a halter,
And sooner 'twill ▪ be granted.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Giovanni,
Sweet Giovanni, there's a sunshine word,
Dear child go with us.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Us? dost think I'll go
And run my head into the hemp?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Best honeysuckle!
One word o'thine will strike the pardon dead.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Thou shalt go a pilgrimage, another time
To the world's end, I charge thee on my blessing,
And husband you must go too.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No, no not I.
I thank you Ursula, I'll not have my foot
Nor hand in any treason.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Is it so much to kneel? you shall say nothing.
Unless you please, leave all the talk to me,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I won't go, though the Duke send for me.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: How? that's a piece a treason.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: So, if I go not,
She'll betray me too; well Giovanni shall go too,
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Let me alone to conjure him.
Shall we go presently, delays are dangerous.
The rascal George is gone too, all forsake me
In my distress.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What will you say Ursula,
When you come there; what will the Dukes think on you?
Or who shall suffer for your impudence?
And what? that is considerable, I have
No mind to go again.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Then I'll spoil the garden,
Break up the hedges, and deface the works
Your darling Giovanni made; I'll let in
a regiment of swine, and all their officers
To undermine the castle he made last,
And fortified with cannon, though I die for't.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: More treason, well I will go, but I hope
You won't trudge this evening, if we must
Resolve upon't, let us do things discreetly.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: That was well said, nay, I am for discretion
For all my haste.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I think it most convenient
To wait his business, coming forth his chamber
Tomorrow morning Ursula, and then let
Good nature's work, to nights no time,
We must consult our pillows; what to say;
And how to place our words.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Now 'tis my best
Pigeon, let's home instantly.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A sober pace goes far, not too fast Ursula,
Remembering the proverb, and what follows;
We should march slow to save me from the gallows.

div.stage: Enter Cornari with a pistol and a rapier. Florelli.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You have had your time of pleasure, can you pray?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray, what do you mean signior.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The lady whom you have enjoyed, commanded
I should present one of these two, or both
In token of her gratitude.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This cannot
Be earnest sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: These are the jewels
Which you must wear sir next your heart: how d'ye
Affect the lustre of this toy? 'tis bright,
But here's a thing will sparkle.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am lost.
Is this the promise of my safety?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes,
this will secure all, thou dull islander,
'Cause you can dance, and vault upon a hobby-horse,
D'ye think to mount madonnas here, and not
Pay for the sweet career. Fool, to thy prayers,
For when these messengers salute thy heart,
Thy soul shall find, I'm an italian,
And won't trust a life to him, whose tongue
Commands my honour.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As much as comes to a Venetians faith,
That believes no man is more to fit die
Than he, that has been capering with my wife.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ye cannot fir forget I was betrayed,
Awake thy conscience, and let that answer
I have obeyed a dire necessity,
And was brought hither by a stratagem.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis all one signior; I presume you gave
Consent to the dear matter of delight,
Which is not held convenient you should talk of.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Hope not to breathe ten minutes, gather up
Those thoughts you would have wait upon you to
Another world.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then 'tis high time to think
Of other matters, though you have cruelly
Resolved there is no safety for your fame,
To let me still be numbered with the living.
(Which if your scattered reason were collected,
I could refute,) but I'll not hope it now,)
Since most ignobly 'gainst the rules of honour,
And faith already forfeit, you will make
This undefenced pile your sacrifice,
Yet do not kill me twice.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Such a rage
Were infinite; practise not cruelty
upon my second life, by murdering my
Eternity, allow to my last breath,
Leave to discharge the weight of many sins
Into the bosom of some confessor.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This may be granted, 'tis not much unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Your charity will think it fit to allow
Some minutes to collect myself.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: To show
My design has no malice in't, I'll do
Your soul that office, though our bodies must not
Enjoy this air together many hours.
I'll send one to you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The innocence of a saint,
Would not secure his life from an Italian
When his revenge is fixed. In what black hour
Did I salute the world, that I am thrown
Upon so hard a fate? it is not fit
To expostulate with heaven, or I could say
Something in my defence, (As I am man)
To keep this mighty rock from falling on me,
My tutelar angel be at counsel with
My thoughts, and if there be a path of safety
Direct my trembling steps to find, and taste it.
sp.stage: Enter Cornari in a friar's habit.
sp.l: Has kept his word, and 'tis no time to trifle,
As you're a priest, and by that sacred order
And scapular you wear, not only hear me
But use your pious art to save from ruin
A man condemned for that which heaven and you
Call virtue, for not doing a black deed
Would damn three souls at once, and if your power
Cannot prevail for mercy to my life,
I challenge you when I am dead, to be
A witness of my innocence.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This has
no shape of a confession.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nor do I
Under that holy seal discourse a story,
Yet father I must throw myself upon
Your charity. Know therefore I am betrayed,
And by the plot of him that owes this palace
(Whose name is never like to meet my knowledge)
Snatched up, one fatal evening, and forced hither
By some dark ministers he had employed
(I know not which way) to this fatal chamber.
I shudder but to name what impious act
Against his own, and his dear lady's honour
He had designed for me; her chaster soul
Should have been stained, in his distrust of heaven,
To bless him with an heir, and her white treasure,
By me a stranger rifled, had not providence.
Chained up our blood, so that the hours he gave
To serve his black ambition, and our lust,
We only spent in prayers for his conversion.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This yet he knows not, and it is not safe
To appear in our own virtue, since the justice
We did our peace, in crossing his expectance
May improve his rage to both our ruins. This
Sad story frights you, there is horror in't,
But 'tis an hour, the last, without some miracle
To rescue me (A man disarmed) from violence,
Nor dare I mock heaven now, or hang upon
My soul the burden of a lie, when 'tis
Taking her last eternal flight, it is not
A fear to die afflicts me, with my faith
And innocence about me; I have looked
Death in the face, and be it thought no boast
To say, I have taught others by example
To march up to the ugliest face of danger.
But to die thus dishonourably, to be
Sent out o'th world i'th dark, without a name
Or any account to those, to whom I owe
My blood, and birth? persons that carry names
Of honour in my country? This doth stagger me
To quit my life, and may excuse my address
To you, who have authority from heaven
To take his fury off, whom otherwise
I expect my violent executioner.
I have some tremblings for his lady, whose
Most holy tears, streamed through my soul compassion,
And charmed my blood, tears, if he durst have patience
Were powerful enough to beg from heaven
That blessing which he fondly thinks to hasten ▪
With loss of his eternity.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.stage: Exit Conrari hastily, having thrown off the habit enter again with Claudiana.
sp.l: Forgive me, o forgive me Claudiana,
And if my sin of forcing thy obedience
Beyond the rules of honour, and of marriage
Have not quite murdered thy affection;
Wish me a little life for my repentance.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: I joy to hear this from you.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.l: There's work within me, and so deep a sense
Of my own shame and sorrow, that I feel
My heart already weeping out a bath
To make thee white again.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, in what best
I understand, I must ask you forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha mine, for what, betraying thee to darkness?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou didst
The impious act by my design, which takes
thy guilt away, and spreads the leprosy
Upon myself.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Although you kill me sir,
I must remove the cloud, and let you see
Me as I am, not changed from my first innocence.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Most easy, where there is
A chaste resolve, and I must tell you sir,
Although I wanted courage to oppose
Your passion, when your reason, and religion
Were under violence of your will, my heart
Resolved to try my own defence, and rather
Than yield myself a shameful spoil to lust,
By my own death to quit my name from scandal;
But providence determined better for me,
And made me worth a stranger's piety,
Whom your choice meant the ruin of my honour;
If this want entertainment in your faith,
'Tis peace to my poor heart that I have many
White witnesses in heaven.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You have done no feats then?
My wife is chaste.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I cannot sir engage
My last breath to a nobler truth.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis so —Ex. Cla.
You may withdraw Claudiana; by what
Has been expressed, though I am satisfied,
You are not guilty in the fact, as I
Expected, 'tis not safe, when I consider
My own fame in the story, that you live sir.
I must not trust you longer with a secret
That by my tameness may hereafter spread
The infamy abroad: there's no avoiding —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Perhaps you have some hope
this engine may deceive me, and my fortune
Not coming better armed, give you the advantage
To use your strength, upon my single person!
I know you are active, but I'll make sure work.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Till now I did not reach the precipice.
My heart would mutiny, but my hands are naked,
And can do nothing.
A knot of murderers! arm me with a sword,
And let me die fighting against you all.
I'll say you're noble hangmen, and not throw
One curse among you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I've one word to say sir.
Let none approach,
The fatal doom I threatened is reversed;
Throw off your wonder, and believe you may
Live long, if not in Venice, and your safety
Is more confirmed at distance, you are noble,
An honour to your nation. Here is gold,
I know not how you may be furnished sir
For travel hence, bills of exchange may fail.
These will defray a present charge; betray
No wonder, take it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll accept your bounty,
And will not ask to whom I owe all this,
Forgive me that. I thought you not so honourable.
So when you please, I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Not yet.
By such attendants ss you came to me,
I have provided sir for your departure.
Your duties gentlemen. You know my purpose.

div.stage: The bravoes blindhim, and bind him as before. Exeunt. Enter Claudiana.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Resume thy place within my soul Claudiana,
When I have done my sorrow for what's passed
We'll smile, and kiss for ever.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Let him rot, and give 'em back the paperkite.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Sir, I send not to you for relief, nor to
Mediate my pardon. I have not lived after
The rate to deserve your bread to feed me,
Nor your breath to save me. I only beg
That you would put me into your prayers,
And forgiveness, and believe, I do not wish life,
But to redeem myself from past impieties,
And satisfy by a repentance the dishonours
Have been done to you, by the worst of men. Malipiero.
This is not his usual style.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And sent a blessing to reward our penitence.
Heaven has a spacious charity.

div.stage: Enter the bravoes, they lay him down, and exeunts Florelli recovers.

sp.p: Where in the name of wonder hast thou been ▪

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I am dropped from the moon.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I was snatched up in a whirlwind,
And dined and supped at Cynthia's own table,
Where I drank all your healths in nectar gentlemen,
Do ye want money? if you have a mind
To return viceroys, let's take shipping instantly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For new discoveries,
A cloud will take us up at sea.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: To drink, and then aboard, no matter whither
I'll keep this for a monument.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do not profane it, 'twas Endymion's pillow
Stuffed with horn shavings of the moon, it had
The virtue when she clapped it o'er my head
To bring me thence invisible through the air;
The moon does moble up herself sometime in't.
Where she will show a quarter face, and was
The first that wore a black bag.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No inquisitions if you will leave Venice.
Let's drink and spoon away with the next vessel.
A hundred leagues hence, I may tell you wonders.
Here is a chime to make ring Oberon
Queen Mab, and all her fairies turn o'th toe boys.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: I could not sleep all this night for dreaming,
O'my poor suckling.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Peace I say and wait
In silence Ursula.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You may excuse me yet.
I would not see his excellence.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: 'Tis not my meaning boy, thou shouldst appear
Unless there be necessity, you may stay, i'the next chamber.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: I beseech you signior, is this grace coming forth.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: I have an humble suit, I must deliver
A paper to his graces own hand,
I hope his grace can read.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Nay, there's no harm in't what if he can,
You will be talking, did not I say
I would speak all myself.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: But Urs. What do you think now will become on's
When you have told your tale, though I am innocent.
It will be no great credit, nor much comfort
To see you whipped my Ursula, I would
Be sorry for my part to peep through a pillory
And have an even reckoning with my ears,
Having no more hair to keep warm, and hide
The poor concavities.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I will so curse you Ursula, and once
A day, bind your body to a pear tree,
And thrash your haunches till you stink again;
For ought I know thou hast committed treason,
look to't, and bring me off with all my quarters
If I be maimed or cropped, I'll flay thee Ursula,
And stuff thy skin with straw, and hang thee up
To keep the fruit from crows, and after burn it.
To kill the caterpillars, come, be wise in time,
And let Thomazo quietly be hanged,
Or headed yet, and talk no more, he is
But one, and has a young neck to endure it.
We are old, and sha'not show with half the grace
Without our heads, 'twill be a goodly sight
To see our faces grin upon two poles,
To tell the gaping world how we came thither
To perch, and stink in unity, be wise,
And leave Thomazo to the law.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Can you be so uncharitable, o tyrant!
sp.l: May it please your excellence, my husband and
Myself.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: She has put me in already.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Humbly beseech a pardon for our son.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Your son Giovanni, where is he?

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: He waits in the next chamber.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Call him in. What is the fact?
It must be an offence next treason, if we
Deny him pardon.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I fear 'tis much about the matter.

sp.speaker: Vr.
sp.l: We do beseech you grant a pardon first,
And than you shall know all.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That were preposterous justice.
Why dost thou kneel Giovanni?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: To beg your mercy sir
To him, for whom my mother kneels

sp.speaker: Vr.
sp.p: No matter what he says, my husband knows it.

sp.speaker: Vr.
sp.l: And if your highness will but grant the pardon,
Your grace shall not repent, but thank me for
The best discovery; I'll not bribe your excellence,
But I will give you for it, what you'll hold
As precious as your dukedom.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The old woman
Raves, you had best send her to the house
Of the insani.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: So she's to be whipped already,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I say nothing,
But that I think my wife will hardly mend upon't.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: On whipping, if it like your highness,
She cannot feel those small corrections.
I have tawed hunting poles, and hemp upon her,
And yet could do no good.

sp.speaker: Ur.
sp.l: Let not your grace mind him, give me a pardon,
And if I do not make good all my promise,
You shall hang my husband, and flay me alive.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Ge't him, thou shouldst have done this afore.
I am prepared, more bone and flesh upon me
If the business come to hanging, were a courtesy.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Nay 'tis there in black and white, you'll find it ▪
Giovanni is your son, that was the gardener,
And he that is in prison poor Thomazo
My lawfully begotten.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: And since concealed out of ambition
To see my own a great man.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I feel the knot under my ear.

sp.speaker: Vr.
sp.p: I durst not trust my husband.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: He has not wit enough to keep my secrets.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O what a blessing has that man whose wife
Knows when to hold her peace.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, if we may compare their tracts of life,
I shall believe your nobleness lived there
In Giovanni, not suppressed in poverty,
And their rude course condition, notwithstanding
The helps of education, which seldom
Do correct nature in Thomazo's low
And abject spirit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'm too full, I must
Disperse my swelling joys or be dissolved,
Summon our friends, invite Bellaura hither.
Art thou my son?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I would I were so blessed.
Jowed you duty sir before, and now
My knees incline with double force to humble
The doubtful Giovanni.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Let that name
Be lost, take all my blessings in Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: What think you of this Roberto.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Why? I think
The Duke is mad, and when he finds his wits
He'll hang us both yet.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now I find the reason.
And secret of my nature: but tell me
What after so long silence, made you now
Open the cloud that had concealed my son?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I know not sir — now Ursula.

sp.speaker: Vr.
sp.l: The weakness of a woman, and a mother
That would be loath to see her natural child
Die like a bird upon a bough for treason,
Nature will work, a mother is a mother,
and your son, by the opening of this riddle
Restored, I hope all shall be well again.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Would I were fair washed, yet out of my pickle.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I wish, I wish I could not think.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: With our most glad embraces let us hold you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Ever a servant to your gravities.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Bellaura, now receive not Giovanni,
But Contarini's son my dear Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My heart hath wings to meet him.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I melt again Ursula, the Duke points at us,
And carries fireworks in his eyes,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Though we did grant a pardon for your son,
You are subject to the censure of our laws
For this imposture.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I knew't would come, now tell-tale, will you beg
The favour we may hang till we be dead?
Sweet Giovanni Thomazo speak for us,
Not guilty my lord, I am not guilty,
Spare me, and let my wife be burned or hanged,
Or drowned, or any thing you shall think fit,
You shall find me reasonable,
Who shall beg our pardon?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let me beseech you for their pardon sir.
They always used me civilly.

sp.speaker: Senator
sp.p: And all of us, this is a day of triumph.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: A jubilee, a jubilee, here comes Thomazo,
I shall speak treason presently.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Now heaven preserve your sweet graces.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Mercy, o mercy, my indulgent father.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: I have procured thy pardon, marry have I child.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: I would 'twere true, thou wert ever a loving crone.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I say thou art pardoned,
You must kneel to me now, and this good
Old man, and ask us blessing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your name is proved Giovanni now, the Duke
Has found another son.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You shall be only punished to return,
And dig as he hath done, and change your name
To Giovanni, nature was not willing
You should forget your trade, where's my Thomazo?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: And you signior Thomazo, that was I?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And you Giovanni with the inside outward

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And must I be a gardener? I am glad on't.
Pray give me a couple of blessings, and a spade,
And fico for this frippery. I'll thank
My destiny that has yet kept my thread
To a better use than hanging.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Let nothing
Of punishment profane this day, I must
Implore your mercy upon this young man,
whose future life may recompense his past
Impieties, and make him serviceable
To honour and good men.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You show with charity,
If I have heard a truth in some sad storeys,
He's yours and pardoned.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You're a miracle
Of goodness, 'tis too much to look upon,
Whom I have with such impudence offended.
Command me sir abroad until by some
Years well employed, a penance for my crimes
I may be thought one worthy to be owned
Your kinsman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Again, welcome my Thomazo,
My dearest pledge, till now I was no father;
In him, the want of hope my thoughts oppressed,
In thee my fortunes, and my name are blessed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
